title: Impeachment inquiry into Bill Clinton
added: On November 19, Ken Starr presented his case against Clinton to the House Committee on the Judiciary. Starr declared that Clinton had repeatedly chosen "deception".<ref name="CUNY"/> In this session, the Democrats on the committee questioned Starr on his methods of investigation.<ref name="CUNY"/>

On November 28, Clinton delivered written answers to 81 questions that the House Committee on the Judiciary had given him.<ref>{{cite web |title=TESTING OF A PRESIDENT; Clinton's Responses to Questions From the House Judiciary Committee (Published 1998) |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/11/28/us/testing-president-clinton-s-responses-questions-house-judiciary-committee.html |website=The New York Times |access-date=1 March 2021 |date=28 November 1998}}</ref><ref name="CNN28nov">{{cite web |title=Republicans disappointed by Clinton's answers to impeachment questions - November 28, 1998 |url=https://www.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/stories/1998/11/28/impeach.republicans/ |website=www.cnn.com |publisher=CNN | agency=AllPolitics |access-date=1 March 2021 |date=28 November 1998}}</ref> Republicans voiced disappointment and outrage at Clinton's questions, which they criticized as being evasive, incomplete, weak in defense, and legalistic.<ref name="CUNY"/><ref name="CNN28nov"/>
